content:
Post-punk has a significant following in Mexico due to its historical and cultural context. The emergence of post-punk in the late 1970s and early 1980s coincided with a period of political and social upheaval in Mexico, including the 1985 earthquake, economic instability, and political corruption. This created a generation of disenchanted youth who found solace in the angsty and introspective music of post-punk bands.

In addition to its cultural relevance, post-punk also had a significant impact on the Mexican music scene, particularly through the influence of bands such as Joy Division, The Cure, and Siouxsie and the Banshees. These bands helped to inspire a generation of Mexican musicians, who in turn created their own unique take on post-punk and related genres.

Furthermore, post-punk's DIY ethos and anti-establishment themes resonated with Mexican audiences who were critical of the government and mainstream culture. The genre also allowed for the exploration of taboo topics such as sexuality and mental health, which were not typically addressed in popular music at the time.

Overall, the popularity of post-punk in Mexico can be attributed to its cultural and historical relevance, its influence on Mexican music, and its themes of rebellion and self-expression.
